name: Hispanic American Music
description: Includes all genres created by Hispanic Americans.

children.name: Afro-Cuban Jazz
children.description: Combines Jazz with the rhythms of Afro-Cuban music.

children.name: Argentine Music
children.description: Music developed by the Argentine people.

children.name: Avanzada
children.description: Fusion of Polka paraguaya and Guarania with elements of Bossa nova and MPB.

children.name: Bachata
children.description: Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.

children.name: Bailecito
children.description: Agile and lively dance derived from Zamacueca, typical of the western and central region of Bolivia.

children.name: Bolero
children.description: Ballad with a 2/4 time signature that appeared in eastern Cuba towards the end of the 19th century.

children.name: Boogaloo
children.description: Upbeat fusion of American Rhythm & Blues and Jazz with Son cubano which originated in the early 1960s in New York City and became popular with both its Black and Latino communities.

children.name: Bullerengue
children.description: Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.

children.name: Caporal
children.description: Bolivian neofolkloric dance music characterized by a double beat bass drum pattern that emerged in the latter half of the twentieth century.

children.name: Carnaval cruceño
children.description: Danceable genre, similar to the Polka, from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.

children.name: Champeta
children.description: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

children.name: Chilean Music
children.description: Music developed by the Chilean people.

children.name: Chuntunqui romántico
children.description: Vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

children.name: Conjunto andino
children.description: Urban folk ensembles using musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association; despite frequent association with Indigenous villages, they bear little resemblance to the Indigenous expressions of the Southern Andes.

children.name: Cuban Music
children.description: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

children.name: Cumbia
children.description: Danceable folk genre formed during the 19th century in Colombia and eastern Panama.

children.name: Currulao
children.description: Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Dembow
children.description: Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.

children.name: Gaita zuliana
children.description: Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.

children.name: Guarania
children.description: Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.

children.name: Hispanic American Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses many varieties of folk traditions from Hispanic America.

children.name: Huayno
children.description: Andean dance music that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.

children.name: Latin Alternative
children.description: Incorporates common elements from Hispanic American Music like Cumbia, Tango or Mexican Music into Rock.

children.name: Latin American Classical Music
children.description: Western Classical Music with influences from Hispanic American Music.

children.name: Latin Disco
children.description: Disco that incorporates elements from Hispanic American Music styles.

children.name: Latin Electronic
children.description: Combines Electronic with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.

children.name: Latin Funk
children.description: Funk combined with Hispanic American Music styles.

children.name: Latin Pop
children.description: Incorporates elements and tropes from Hispanic and Latin American forms of music into a commercial Pop context.

children.name: Latin Rock
children.description: Fusion of Rock, often Psychedelic Rock, with Latin American rhythms, especially Afro-Latin genres.

children.name: Latin Soul
children.description: Soul combined with Hispanic American Music, such as Salsa and Mambo.

children.name: Merengue
children.description: Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.

children.name: Mexican Music
children.description: Music of Mexico and those deeply rooted in Mexican traditions.

children.name: New Mexico Music
children.description: Derived from the Traditional Folk Music of New Mexico mixed with influences from Western, Country and Norteño, particularly associated with Spanish-speaking Nuevomexicanos.

children.name: Nueva canción latinoamericana
children.description: Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.

children.name: Onda nueva
children.description: Based on Joropo, it incorporates elements of Bossa nova and Jazz.

children.name: Pasillo
children.description: Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European Waltz and often performed with guitar and mandolin.

children.name: Peruvian Music
children.description: Music developed by the Peruvian people.

children.name: Polka paraguaya
children.description: Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.

children.name: Porro
children.description: Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

children.name: Purísima
children.description: Nicaraguan Hymns to the Immaculate Conception of Mary, sung during holiday celebrations and in liturgical or parochial services.

children.name: Reggaetón
children.description: Rooted in Dancehall and mainly characterized by its heavy emphasis on the "dembow" rhythm; developed in Puerto Rico in the early 1990s under heavy influence from Hip Hop.

children.name: Rhumba
children.description: Commercial adaptation of various Latin American genres; developed during the 1930s as the so-called "rhumba craze" unfolded in the United States.

children.name: Rioplatense Music
children.description: Music developed by the people of the Rio de la Plata region.

children.name: Rock andino
children.description: Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.

children.name: Salsa
children.description: Often incorporating congas, timbales and bongos as well as smaller instruments, such as maracas, clave and güiro.

children.name: Son de pascua
children.description: Lively instrumental Christmas songs from Central America composed in 6/8 or triple meter.

children.name: Son nica
children.description: Nicaraguan popular rhythm in distinctive guitar strums, with lyrics relating to the countryside and peasant life.

children.name: Tamborera
children.description: Panamanian popular genre which mixes local Tamborito with Cuban Music rhythms featuring the tambora as the main percussion instrument.

children.name: Tropicanibalismo
children.description: Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.

children.name: Vallenato
children.description: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.

children.name: Vals venezolano
children.description: Venezuelan dance music that employs heavy use of syncopation, complex rhythms, and regional instruments.

children.name: Xuc
children.description: Danceable style from El Salvador developed in the 1940s.
